docs.snippet: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his delegation escaped unhurt today when a bomb exploded along their motorcade route. Four vehicles were damaged, including the car carrying Mr. Shultz's wife, as the group traveled toward La Paz from the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his delegation escaped unhurt today when a bomb exploded along their motorcade route. Four vehicles were damaged, including the car carrying Mr. Shultz's wife, as the group traveled toward La Paz from the airport. She was unhurt.

headline.main: Shultz Caravan Is Bomb Target On Bolivia Visit

docs.snippet: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua offered today to renew peace talks with the contras, either in Managua or Washington. Mr. Ortega, who is visiting Ecuador, also criticized the United States Senate for approving a package of aid for...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua offered today to renew peace talks with the contras, either in Managua or Washington. Mr. Ortega, who is visiting Ecuador, also criticized the United States Senate for approving a package of aid for the rebels, calling it an act of ''aggression.'' He demanded that such aid be stopped.

docs.snippet: LEAD:  Tennis  Lendl Beats Connors: Ivan Lendl defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Player's International tournament in Toronto. Lendl, the defending champion, overcame Connors in a 2-hour-10-minute match played...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Tennis Lendl Beats Connors: Ivan Lendl defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Player's International tournament in Toronto. Lendl, the defending champion, overcame Connors in a 2-hour-10-minute match played in 104-degree heat at the National Tennis Centre at York University.

docs.snippet: LEAD: THE familiar arguments over United States policy on Central America echoed on Capitol Hill last week as the Senate took its 23d vote in the last five years on assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The trade bill signed yesterday by President Reagan includes everything from accounting changes, symbolic amendments and special favors to broad policy measures that may eventually give the Government a much stronger hand in trade talks.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN, in signing the 1,000-page trade bill into law, declared that it would ''help us continue our efforts to open markets.'' He thus reversed his earlier veto of an almost identical trade bill. This time he went with those advisers who said the second bill, despite some flaws, was essential to expanding ''free and fair'' trade - and to protecting Republican Party interests in the coming Presidential and
